So ladies and gentlemen, it's 10 minutes to 12. I think we have time for two additional questions and then we could speed a lot of this for lunch. I think next question will come from John Lawson, yes.

Thanks, John Lawson from Citi. Coming back to China, are you or your joint venture being asked at the moment still to produce a local brand for the market? And if you are, what is your response to that? And I think one of your peers recently said that profit per unit in China had probably now peaked. Is that also your view? Thanks.
The right question for – who wants to start? I think the Chairman starts.
I mean, regarding a local brand, we are at the moment in negotiations. And I would leave it like that at the moment.
Next one, Jose Asumendi and then Aleksej Wunrau.

Thanks very much. Jose Asumendi, RBS. Just going back to raw materials – back here – coming back to raw materials, I was wondering if you could just share, especially on the steel suppliers, what kind of price increases they are requesting and whether they can pass on these raw material price increases on a quarterly basis?

And second on pricing, I see or I hear very conservative comments from your side, and could you just put into context how much pricing power did you lose during the crisis and how much have you recovered already until 2010? And then third one, on electric cars in China. I believe you want to introduce an electric car with your partner in China. I was wondering, which platform will you use and second, will it be sold under a BMW brand? Thanks.
Okay. We'll start with Mr. Eichiner.

Well, in order to manage the material cost, we apply two different strategies. One is hedging which we basically have for precious materials and a few others and the other is long-term contracts. On the steel side, we are using long-term contracts and so actually, we are on the safe side up to the middle of the year and then we have to – up to this point in time, we have to – fear those contracts will run out. We have to renew those sales contracts and then the pricing we paid basically takes a certain role. So that's why we see some risk on this side as well. But as we said, we try to handle the volatility on the material cost side with those two instruments.

Now, the question about the pricing and what we lost during the crisis. Well, we lost between 4% to 5%. And as I said already today, we could regain 2% in 2010. That's why I'm saying there's still a way to go. I mean, it's still half of potential is to improve pricing with the introduction of the new volume models.
So last part of the question, the E cars in China, plant platforms, Mr. Reithofer?
I mean, our new energy vehicle for China will be a 5 Series plug-in hybrid. And the development phase is already underway. And we will start to produce the car before 2015.
So last question, Aleksej Wunrau?

Yes, thank you. Aleksej Wunrau, BHF-Bank. Just one question remaining. I wonder if you could elaborate on the extent by which low interest rates helped not only the profitability of the Financial Service business, but also underlying demand in 2010, especially given the fact that your Financial Service assets increased by quite a lot? And based on that, my question of whether demand could adversely affected, if we were to see a reversion of the interest rate trend not only in China, but also in Europe, and possibly in the U.S. this or next year?
Yes, right. Question for Mr. Eichiner?

Well, clearly the favorable interest rates in 2010 supported Financial Service's performance. The margin was really high. It was a record margin. We could realize in this year and looking forward now and we all know at a point in time, interest rates will increase. There will come some pressure on the margin side and the question is, how much of this will be compensated by lower provisions on the risk side?

So we have to look at both sides. It's clear in the cycle with increasing interest rates, there will be some pressure on margin. But we have to look at the same point in time, what's going on, on the risk side and then you get the complete picture. And as I said, my expectation is that we get some relief on the risk side as we see signals that our used car pricing is going up and is quite stable. So that maybe we should be able to maintain our guidance for a 19% return on equity over the next couple of years.
Would that ...
Yeah?
Just as a follow-up, would that mean that you have to pass on the burden of higher refinancing costs on to your customers and would that mean that they would have to pay higher prices for their cars?

I mean, there is always a question of price acceptance in this context and we all know out of history that this is lagging. So it will take some time until consumers will accept that there is now a higher level of interest that has got to be paid. So we are talking about the time lag if this development will really happen, right? So that's why I'm talking about the pressure until we are able to increase interest rates in our contracts for a certain period of time.

So, ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for your question. Let's have lunch together. Both Mr. Reithofer and Mr. Eichiner will be present for lunch. This will give you all an opportunity to chat with them.
Once again, thank you very much for your interest.
